1.title: Week 1: Intro to Microcontrollers
1.description: Hardware, inputs/outputs, MakeCode basics, events & sequencing.

questions.question: What is a microcontroller?
options: A tiny computer on a chip
questions.explanation: A microcontroller is a small computer on a single chip that reads inputs and controls outputs.
questions.definition: MICROCONTROLLER — a tiny computer on one chip, used in gadgets and embedded systems.
questions.hint: Think: the micro:bit has one on board.

questions.question: Which of these is an INPUT on the micro:bit?
questions.explanation: Buttons are inputs; the LED matrix and speaker are outputs.
questions.definition: INPUT — information that comes into the device (e.g., buttons, sensors).
questions.hint: Can you press it to send a signal?

questions.question: Which block runs ONCE when the program starts?
questions.explanation: “on start” runs once at the beginning. Great for initial messages or setup.

questions.question: In MakeCode, what does this do?
questions.explanation: Blocks inside a forever loop repeat continuously.

questions.question: What best describes the LED display?
questions.explanation: The LED display shows information to the user, so it’s an output.

questions.question: Which pair is correctly matched?
questions.explanation: Temperature sensor is an input; speaker is an output; accelerometer is an input; button is an input.

questions.question: Where can you test your code without a physical micro:bit?
questions.explanation: MakeCode includes a simulator to test code before flashing.
questions.definition: SIMULATOR — software that mimics real hardware behaviour.

questions.question: Match terms to definitions.
questions.explanation: Event triggers; sequence is order; debug is fixing mistakes.

questions.question: Which statement is TRUE about 'on button A pressed'?
options: It runs in a loop automatically
It runs when you press A
questions.explanation: Event code runs when the event happens.

questions.question: Which is the best description of a PROGRAM?
options: A set of instructions a computer follows
An image on the LED matrix
questions.explanation: A program is a set of instructions designed to perform tasks.
questions.definition: PROGRAM — a precise list of instructions a computer follows.

questions.question: Why might your program NOT appear on the micro:bit after download?
questions.explanation: All listed causes are common issues.

questions.question: Which pair shows INPUT → PROCESS → OUTPUT correctly?
questions.explanation: Button (input) → logic/compute (process) → show icon (output).

2.title: Week 2: Events & Random
2.description: Button events, accelerometer events, random numbers, simple probability; revisits Week 1 I/O.

questions.question: What does 'random 1 to 6' represent?
options: A number chosen by chance from 1..6
questions.explanation: Each number 1–6 has equal chance, like a dice.
questions.definition: RANDOM — selection by chance from a range.

questions.question: When does code inside 'on button A pressed' run?
questions.explanation: It’s an event: code runs when the event happens.

questions.question: Which is a fair six-sided dice?
questions.explanation: Fair means equal probability for all six outcomes.

questions.question: What will this show?
questions.code:
on button A pressed
    set roll to random 1 to 6
    show number roll
questions.explanation: Each press shows a fresh random dice number.

questions.question: Coin flip probabilities: what is the chance of Heads?
questions.explanation: Ideal coin: 1 out of 2 outcomes.

questions.question: Which event uses the accelerometer?
questions.explanation: Shake is detected by the accelerometer sensor.

questions.question: Debug this dice code: Why do two numbers flash quickly?
questions.code:
on button A pressed
    show number random 1 to 6
    show number random 1 to 6
options: Because it shows two random numbers in a row
questions.explanation: Two different random calls → two numbers shown fast.

questions.question: Match event to trigger.
questions.explanation: Start → begin; A+B → both down; shake → accelerometer.

questions.question: Expected results: In 60 dice rolls, how many 3s would you expect (roughly)?
Which best describes an EVENT?
options: A trigger like a press or shake
questions.explanation: Events trigger code to run.

questions.question: Revision: Which is an OUTPUT?
questions.explanation: LEDs show info → output; the others are inputs.

questions.question:
Pseudocode: What does this do?

on button A pressed
  set x to random 1..10
  if x > 7 then show "Big" else show "Small"
options: Shows Big if x is 8,9,10; otherwise Small
questions.explanation: Conditional branches based on the random value.

3.title: Week 3: Conditionals & Decisions
3.description: If/else, comparisons, Rock–Paper–Scissors; revision of events & random.

questions.question: Which comparison checks 'equal to'?
questions.explanation: = means the two values are the same.

questions.question: What does ELSE mean in an if/else?
options: Runs when the IF is true
Runs when the IF is false
questions.explanation: ELSE is the 'otherwise' branch when IF is false.
questions.hint: Think: If not A, then do B.

questions.question: Rock–Paper–Scissors: What beats Rock?
questions.explanation: Paper covers Rock.

questions.question: Debug: Goal is 'Go outside if sunny OR warm'. What's wrong?
questions.code:
set isSunny to true
set isWarm to false
if isSunny and isWarm then
    show string "Go outside!"
else
    show string "Stay in"
questions.explanation: Use OR if either condition should allow going outside.

questions.question: What will this show?
questions.code:
set n to random 1 to 10
if n > 5 then show "Big" else show "Small"
questions.explanation: Condition splits the range.

questions.question: Which operator means 'not equal'?
questions.explanation: ≠ means the two values differ.

questions.question: Match outcomes (RPS).
questions.explanation: Standard RPS rules.

questions.question: Revision: Which block waits for a user action before running?
questions.explanation: Event handlers wait for the event.

questions.question:
Pseudocode: Predict the output.

set score to 0
on button A pressed
  set x to random 0..1
  if x = 1 then change score by 1 else change score by -1

What happens to score over many presses?
options: Goes up or down by chance
questions.explanation: Random 0/1 gives a fair chance to go up or down.

questions.question: Which statement is TRUE?
options: If and else always both run
Else runs only if the if-condition is false
questions.explanation: Else is the alternative when if is false.

questions.question: Nested decisions: What will show when temp=15?
questions.code:
if temp < 10 then show "Freezing"
else if temp < 20 then show "Cold"
else show "Warm"
questions.explanation: 15 is less than 20 but not less than 10.

questions.question:
Revision logic + events: What must be true for this to show "Win"?

on button A pressed
  set c to random 1..3
  if c = 2 then show "Win" else show "Try again"
options: Only if button B is pressed
questions.explanation: Win branch triggers only if c equals 2.

4.title: Week 4: Variables & Thresholds (Sensors)
4.description: Using variables to store sensor readings, comparing to thresholds; revision of conditionals.

questions.question: What is a VARIABLE?
options: A box that stores a value
questions.explanation: Variables store changing values like numbers or text.

questions.question: What is a THRESHOLD?
options: A boundary value to compare against
questions.explanation: A limit that triggers actions when crossed.

questions.question: Which stores the current temperature?
questions.explanation: The temperature block reads the on-board sensor.

questions.question: What will this show if lightLevel = 30?
questions.code:
set lightLevel to light level
if lightLevel < 50 then show "Too Dark" else show "OK"
questions.explanation: 30 < 50, so the 'Too Dark' branch runs.

questions.question: Which line changes a variable by 1?
questions.explanation: ‘change by’ adds or subtracts from the current value.

questions.question: Store and compare: Which is correct?
options: set t to temperature; if t > 25 then show "Hot"
if t > 25 then set t to temperature
set t to button A; if t > 25 then show "Hot"
questions.explanation: Store the reading in a variable, then compare.

questions.question: Match concept to example.
questions.explanation: Variable stores; threshold is a boundary; sensor measures.

questions.question:
Pseudocode: What does this do?

set minLight to 40
set temp to temperature
set light to light level
if temp < 16 or light < minLight then show "Help" else show "Fine"
options: Shows Help only if both are low
Shows Help if either temperature is low or light is low
questions.explanation: OR means either condition triggers the alert.

questions.question: Debug: Why might this never show "OK"?
questions.code:
set t to temperature
if t > 100 then show "Too Hot" else show "OK"
options: Because t is not a variable
questions.explanation: Typical indoor temps rarely exceed 100°C.

questions.question: Combined logic: What shows if temp=18 and light=60?
questions.code:
if temp < 16 then show "Cold"
else if light < 50 then show "Dark"
else show "OK"
questions.explanation: Neither condition is true, so 'OK'.

questions.question:
Variables: What happens?

set x to 5
change x by -2
set x to x * 3
show number x
Revision (Week 3): Which condition is TRUE?
questions.explanation: 12 is greater than 8.

5.title: Week 5: Loops & First Game
5.description: repeat/for/while/forever, timing (pause/millis), sprites & collisions; revision of variables and logic.

questions.question: What does a FOREVER loop do?
questions.explanation: Code inside forever keeps running.

questions.question: What does 'repeat 3 times' mean?
questions.explanation: A counted loop with a fixed number of iterations.

questions.question: What does 'pause 500' do inside a loop?
questions.explanation: 500 ms = 0.5 seconds.

questions.question: Counting: What will display?
questions.code:
set n to 1
repeat 4 times
  show number n
  change n by 1
questions.explanation: Starts at 1 and increments each loop.

questions.question: Which is best for a game loop that updates movement?
questions.explanation: Games commonly use a forever/game loop.

questions.question: Sprite movement: What happens?
questions.code:
set p to sprite at x 0 y 2
repeat 4 times
  change p x by 1
  pause 200
questions.explanation: x increases → moves right.

questions.question: Timing: Why use millis or pauses?
questions.explanation: Timing controls pacing and responsiveness.

questions.question: Match loop to use-case.
questions.explanation: forever → continuous; repeat → fixed count; while → until condition changes.

questions.question: What’s TRUE about this while loop?
questions.code:
set n to 10
while n > 5
  show number n
  change n by -2
questions.explanation: When n becomes 4, condition is false, loop stops.

questions.question: Combined logic + loops: What shows at end?
questions.code:
set score to 0
repeat 5 times
  set x to random 0..1
  if x = 1 then change score by 1
show number score
questions.explanation: Five Bernoulli trials; result is 0..5 successes.

questions.question: Game logic: Which statement is TRUE for collisions?
options: You must check if two sprites touch to count a hit
Sprites can’t move on a 5×5 grid
questions.explanation: Collision detection is a code check between sprites’ positions.

questions.question: Revision (Week 4 + Week 3): What shows if speed=3?
questions.code:
if speed > 5 then show "Fast"
else if speed >= 3 then show "Okay"
else show "Slow"
questions.explanation: 3 meets the ≥ 3 condition.
